title: Do Greeks consider Anatolia their stolen land? - Quora

response.answer_text: I would say that the Greeks are deeply saddened by the loss of Constantinople, the Black Sea coast of Pontus, the occupation of northern Cyprus and the coasts of Asia Minor. However, none of these territories have claimed for decades (except in the case of occupation of northern Cyprus). On the contrary, someone has to focus to the rhetoric of their neighboring Anatolia in recent years to understand who sees and discover enemies everywhere, threatens everyone and consumes its gross national income for super-sized military equipment, invading Syria, blackmailing the European Union and playing with the intelligence of all of us, with the sole aim of reviving the glamor and size of the Ottoman Empire.

Greeks are steady 10 million Greeks for ages, they have no need for more land. Moreover Anatolia was of mainly ancient Greek colonies or part of Greek-Roman Byzantium that is gone long ago. Greek borders are stabilized ending of the Ottoman Empire border wars and Greece try hard to keep up with the demanding EU requirements and financials are at priority under the present crisis. Of course Greece has to live with neighboring Turkey with an aggressive Foreign Policy and weapons-building for war-like operations, but Greece since ancient times used to have that and knowingly has to live with it. No Greek consider Anatolia as stolen land.

Absolutely they do! The coast of Asia Minor, Eastern Thrace, the Pontus, Constantinople and Cyprus have been Greek for thousands of years. This is why there were millions of Greeks living in these lands prior to the 1922 population exchange. These areas at no different than those the Greeks successfully liberated to form what is now modern Greece. The only difference is that these areas were not liberated. The Greeks did try to free the west coast of Asia Minor in the 1919–1922 Greco-Turkish war but didn’t succeed.

Νο. It is probable that the Ancient greeks had indeed a sort of Anatolian homeland and also that they were mixed with some Westerners. But it has not been proved. As for modern Greeks, they are not so much into blaming the Turks. They rather consider that they have been moved from Anatolia because of the Western way of life, that brought war with it.

Greeks aren't native Anatolians. Only in the aegian Coast of Turkey, thats it. We Turks don't call half of europe turkic land aswell because of the Scythians, Sarmatians, Cimmerians, Huns, Ottomans, Avars, Bulgars and so on..
Stolen? Of course not! We would have to be really stupid if Anatolia was just stolen. It was conquered by the Turks, and that's all!
Nothing is “stolen”. Turks captured Anatolia six centuries ago. I don't think Greeks still care, save a few fanatic ultra right weirdos.
Only some extreme nationalists view it that way. There are no greeks in anatolia anymore so we dont consider it our stolen land.
